user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_BSP_Unlock_Impl:
```c
void OS_BSP_Unlock_Impl(void)
{
    int status;

    status = pthread_mutex_unlock(&OS_BSP_GenericLinuxGlobal.AccessMutex);
    if (status < 0)
    {
        BSP_DEBUG("pthread_mutex_unlock: %s\n", strerror(status));
    }
    else
    {
        /* Restore previous cancellability state */
        pthread_setcancelstate(OS_BSP_GenericLinuxGlobal.AccessCancelState, NULL);
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function OS_BSP_Unlock_Impl:
#define BSP_DEBUG(__VA_ARGS__) 
...
OS_BSP_GenericLinuxGlobalData_t OS_BSP_GenericLinuxGlobal
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
#define BSP_DEBUG(__VA_ARGS__)
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation. The BSP_DEBUG macro expands to nothing, so the if (status < 0) branch contains only an empty statement (the macro expansion plus the trailing semicolon). That branch can still be taken at runtime (it is not unreachable), and the else branch remains reachable when status >= 0. Therefore there is no unreachable code introduced by the empty macro definition.
